December 27, 2024January 7, 2025

![](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/2024-EOY-Recap_Header.jpg)

As 2024 concludes, we’re looking back at the products, updates and initiatives that marked a year of innovation at Meta. This was a year of pushing our products forward while adding helpful new features and working to keep people safe across our platforms.

These highlights provide a quick overview of some of the year’s biggest accomplishments as we gear up for 2025.

## Looking Forward With Open Source AI, Orion and More

[![A drawing of glasses facing charts and graphs](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/01_Innovation_Orion.png?w=150&h=150&crop=1&resize=220%2C220)](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/01_Innovation_Orion.png) In 2024, we introduced [Meta AI](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/04/meta-ai-assistant-built-with-llama-3/), an AI assistant that we believe to be the most advanced one available for free.

[![A drawing of a human-like Llama wearing glasses and a blue scarf](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/01_Innovation_Llama.png?w=150&h=150&crop=1&resize=220%2C220)](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/01_Innovation_Llama.png)

Built using Llama, our open source AI model, Meta AI can be used across Meta’s apps to help you get things done, learn, create and connect with the things and people that matter to you. It can help you plan a trip, study and more, and it’s on track to be the world’s most used AI assistant by the end of the year, with nearly 600 million monthly active users.

Earlier this year, our Founder & CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, [wrote an open letter](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/07/open-source-ai-is-the-path-forward/) about open source AI’s potential to effect meaningful change. With more than 650 million downloads, Llama has become a popular choice in the open source community. [![A drawing of a planet that looks like Saturn](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/01_Innovation_Threads-Fediverse.png?w=150&h=150&crop=1&resize=220%2C220)](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/01_Innovation_Threads-Fediverse.png) We’ve seen [companies employing Llama](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/05/how-companies-are-using-meta-llama/) to build technology for the public good, from [localizing educational material](https://ai.meta.com/blog/foondamate-study-aid-education-llama/) to [increasing access to medical information](https://ai.meta.com/blog/bimedix-built-with-llama/) in low-resource communities.

In addition to AI, we made industry-leading advancements in AR when we introduced [Orion](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/09/introducing-orion-our-first-true-augmented-reality-glasses/), our first true AR glasses prototype, a key part of our vision to build the next computing platform that puts people at the center so they can be more present, connected and empowered in the world. [![A drawing of a planet highlighting different server locations on different continents](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/01_Innovation_AI-Expansion.png?w=150&h=150&crop=1&resize=220%2C220)](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/01_Innovation_AI-Expansion.png) We also released [Meta Quest 3S](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/09/meta-quest-3s-our-most-affordable-mixed-reality-headset/), our most affordable mixed reality headset yet, and brought to market new styles and smart features for [Ray-Ban Meta glasses](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/09/ray-ban-meta-glasses-new-ai-features-and-partner-integrations/), like helping you remember where you parked and answering questions based on what you’re looking at.

And we made significant progress integrating Threads into the [fediverse](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/06/what-is-the-fediverse/), a global social network of interoperable servers.

## Adding the Features You Asked For

[![A drawing of a storefront](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/02_FOA_WA-Conversations.png?w=150&h=150&crop=1&resize=220%2C220)](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/02_FOA_WA-Conversations.png)

We’re always looking to enhance your experience across our family of apps by adding features that continually raise the bar, and this year was no different. [![A drawing of a woman surrounded by objects/symbols of different technological functions, including a coffee cup and a light bulb](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/01_Innovation_AI-Assistant.png?w=150&h=150&crop=1&resize=220%2C220)](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/01_Innovation_AI-Assistant.png)

For WhatsApp, we [improved call quality](https://www.instagram.com/metanewsroom/p/DDfDAW-RkNA/) and made in-group calling more flexible, plus we introduced [enhanced AI features](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/06/new-ai-tools-meta-verified-and-more-for-businesses-on-whatsapp/) for business chats and a new way to [schedule events](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/05/events-in-whatsapp-communities/). Over on Threads, we added exciting new [web features](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/08/new-threads-features-for-creators-and-businesses/) to help businesses and creators get the most out of the platform – insights, post scheduling and multiple drafts.

[![A drawing of a light bulb](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/02_FOA_Threads-Insights.png?w=150&h=150&crop=1&resize=220%2C220)](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/02_FOA_Threads-Insights.png)We also focused on making sure your experience on Instagram reflects you – who you are, what you want to see and what you create.

[![An illustration of the Facebook logo surrounded by symbols of interactivity, including a painter's palette and a bicycle](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/02_FOA_FBIRL.png?w=150&h=150&crop=1&resize=220%2C220)](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/02_FOA_FBIRL.png) In addition to features allowing you to [edit DMs and pin chats](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/03/instagram-dm-updates/), we introduced new [ways to connect](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/11/new-ways-to-connect-through-dms/) through Instagram DMs, including nicknames and location sharing, making Instagram an even more vibrant place to connect.

[![An illustration of photographs symbolizing Instagram surrounded by several symbols of different functions a user might add to their algorithm, for instance a musical note](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/02_FOA_IG-Stickers.png?w=150&h=150&crop=1&resize=220%2C220)](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/02_FOA_IG-Stickers.png)

We know people want to be able to shape their experience on Instagram as their interests and passions change, which is why we started testing a new way to [reset the recommendations](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/11/introducing-recommendations-reset-instagram/) you see on Instagram’s Explore, Reels and Feed. And for creators, Instagram’s new [trial reels](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/12/trial-reels-try-content-non-followers-first-see-what-perfoms-best/) let creators show your reels to non-followers first to test how they perform.

## Keeping Our Platforms Safe

[![A drawing of a teen surrounded by symbols of interactivity, communication and safety, for instance a lock and Meta's chat-bubble symbol for messaging](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/03_Safety_Teen-Accounts-1.png?w=150&h=150&crop=1&resize=220%2C220)](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/03_Safety_Teen-Accounts-1.png)

In 2024, we stayed vigilant about security and safety, adapting our platforms for an evolving digital landscape.

We introduced Instagram [Teen Accounts](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/09/instagram-teen-accounts/), giving teens built-in protections which limit who can contact them and the content they see. [![An illustration of a paintbrush painting white over a number of different scenes, such as a living room](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/02_FOA_IG-Reccomendation-Reset.png?w=150&h=150&crop=1&resize=220%2C220)](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/02_FOA_IG-Reccomendation-Reset.png) We [launched a new education campaign](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/10/instagram-campaign-protect-teens-sextortion-scams) to help teens and parents spot sextortion scams and we [collaborated with](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/09/preventing-suicide-and-self-harm-content-spreading-online/) experts and peers to help prevent the spread of suicide and self-harm content online.

To help stop celeb-bait ads and speed up account recovery, we began [testing facial recognition technology](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/10/testing-combat-scams-restore-compromised-accounts/). [![A smartphone showing different functions as physical buttons, like a video camera and the chat/Messenger icon](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/03_Safety_Messenger-E2EE-1-e1735066121158.png?w=150&h=150&crop=1&resize=220%2C220)](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/03_Safety_Messenger-E2EE-1-e1735066121158.png) This innovative, easy verification method ensures the right person accesses the right account. And we’re protecting communications between you and the people important to you. [![](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/03_Safety_Facial-Rec-1.png?w=150&h=150&crop=1&resize=220%2C220)](https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/03_Safety_Facial-Rec-1.png)[End-to-end encryption](https://about.fb.com/news/2024/03/end-to-end-encryption-on-messenger-explained/) on Messenger secures your conversations by making it so that nobody sees them except you and the people you’re messaging with.

We spent 2024 innovating, updating and protecting – pushing technology forward while keeping your experience secure. It was a strong year, and we’re excited for the next one.

# Tech trends 2024

20/03/2024

Meta IT, a technology and innovation company focused on digital transformation and evolution, has released its 2024 Tech Trends report on technology market trends. The company surveyed top executives to understand industry outlooks and identify crucial areas for business growth. The Meta IT experts, Marcos Machado (Managing Director) and Simone Lettieri (CDO), were joined by other influential figures in the industry such as Gustavo Franca (Global CIO at [Gerdau](https://www2.gerdau.com/)), Alexandre Villeroy (CIO at [Acelen](https://ri.acelen.com.br/en/the-company/corporate-profile/)), Helio Matsumoto (CIO at Sicredi), Alexandre Telles (CIO at [Ajinomoto](https://www.ajinomoto.com/)), Lilian Hoffmann (Executive Director of Technologies and Innovation at BP), and Wanderley Baccala (Digital Hub Executive Director at Globo).

The report, accessible on their website [https://metait.ai/tech-trends-2024/](/tech-trends-2024/), highlights eight key trends shaping the year. Here’s a quick overview of each:

## More than just transformation, digital evolution

There is an ongoing need for continuous improvement. It’s not just about efficiency, but also driving better experiences for both employees and customers. Digital evolution goes beyond technology, encompassing cultural and organizational shifts focused on people.

“Embracing relevant trends and efficiently integrating them into daily operations is essential. Digital evolution represents a conscious and strategic journey towards tangible results, not just a passing trend,” explains Marcos Machado, Managing Director at Meta IT.

## The year of operational efficiency

2024 is the year of operational efficiency; after all, adopting solutions that enable a company’s evolution is important, but what truly makes a difference is not about having cutting-edge technology, but rather being aligned with customer needs and having an organizational culture compatible with the use of these technologies, fully leveraging them. The goal is to [streamline operations](/production-planning-sap/), maximize resource utilization, and ultimately [support a long-term evolutionary strategy](/solucoes/digital-strategy/).

## Increasingly intelligent artificial intelligence

Following a strong 2023, [Artificial Intelligence (AI)](/solucoes/process-automation-optimization/) remains a major focus. The report highlights its potential for driving experimentation, new opportunities, and innovation through generative AI, which can create original content and learn complex patterns.

“Companies continue to recognize the role of technology as a facilitator in addressing business challenges that impact business, social, and environmental issues. In other words, innovations will not replace, but rather demand adaptation and improvement of human functions,” emphasizes Simone Lettieri, CDO at Meta IT.

## Digital Twins, the best of both worlds

“Digital twins” are real-time virtual representations of physical objects or processes that allow for precise simulations and optimization, like in equipment operation. According to data from Grand View Research, the global market for this technology is expected to exceed $25 billion in revenue by 2025.

## Automating processes means making work easier

[Process automation](/solucoes/process-automation-optimization/) is about making people’s work easier, but it is not just about that. The benefits of automation go far beyond, resulting in noticeable precision, with reduced errors and greater agility in task performance. It goes hand-in-hand with process optimization to improve efficiency, reduce costs, and meet customer demands.

## The transformative power of quantum computing

Quantum computing combines aspects of computing, physics, and mathematics, using quantum mechanics to solve complex problems much faster than traditional computers. There are already some promising applications of quantum computing that simulate supercomputers in commercial use with a focus on logistic optimization.

## It’s all about people, culture, work, and performance

Companies with higher digital maturity tend to invest more in automation and innovation that facilitates work. This is because [they have a culture that embraces technology](/hr-role-digital-transformation/), allowing employees and customers to collaborate more effectively.

“At Meta IT, we believe digital transformation thrives on putting people first. Technology is our tool, but it’s the human factor that unlocks its potential. This collaborative approach fuels operational efficiency and drives growth for our clients,” concludes Marcos Machado, Managing Director at Meta IT.

Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg says there are complex copyright questions around scraping data to train AI models, but he suggests the individual work of most creators isn’t valuable enough for it to matter. In an interview with _The Verge_ deputy editor Alex Heath, Zuckerberg said Meta will likely strike “certain partnerships” for useful content. But if others demand payment, then — as it’s [done with news outlets](https://www.theverge.com/2023/8/1/23815994/meta-facebook-instagram-canada-news-act-blocking) — the company would prefer to walk away.







“I think individual creators or publishers tend to overestimate the value of their specific content in the grand scheme of this,” Zuckerberg said [in the interview](https://www.theverge.com/e/24017522), which coincides with Meta’s annual Connect event. “My guess is that there are going to be certain partnerships that get made when content is really important and valuable.” But if creators are concerned or object, “when push comes to shove, if they demanded that we don’t use their content, then we just wouldn’t use their content. It’s not like that’s going to change the outcome of this stuff that much.”

Meta Connect 2024 ended a week ago and it was probably one of their most impressive showcases to date. Packed with reveals, updates, demonstrations, and some AI magic, Meta pulled out the stops to show the world what they’re working on.

So, we at SideQuest have rounded up the 7key highlights from Meta Connect 2024 that we think you need to know about!

# 1\. Quest 3S launch

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*VDUf0y8xEa-7WfRrvVUQhA.png)

Less than 2 minutes into the keynote presentation, Mark Zuckerberg revealed the Quest 3S— [possibly the most important VR headset launch in 2024](https://medium.com/sidequestvr/quest-3s-could-be-the-most-important-vr-headset-of-2024-4b8da943692a).

With [preorders](https://www.meta.com/gb/quest/quest-3s/) going live as soon as the keynote ended, the Quest 3S presents a more budget-friendly version of the flagship Quest 3 and will launch on **October 15** with prices starting at **$299** for the 128GB model and rising to **$399** for the 256GB model.

Additionally, all preorders and post-launch purchases (until announced otherwise) will come with a **3-month free trial of** [**Meta’s Quest+** **subscription service**](https://www.meta.com/gb/meta-quest-plus/) and a free copy of the hotly anticipated [**Batman: Arkham Shadow**](https://www.meta.com/en-gb/experiences/batman-arkham-shadow/3551691271620960/). Additionally, if you [order Quest 3S through Meta](https://www.meta.com/gb/quest/quest-3s/), you’ll get a **1-year limited warranty** on the device and its boxed contents.

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/0*Eq12DgyqBffLHGfm.png)

A comparison between pancake lenses found in the Quest 3 (left) and fresnel lenses found in Quest 2 and Quest 3S (right).

Regarding specifications, the Quest 3S is similar to its bigger brother, the Quest 3, while including older elements from Quest 2 to keep the price low (looking at you, fresnel lenses!). However, the other specifications, including the all-important Qualcomm Snapdragon XR2 Gen 2 chipset and 8GB RAM, are the same as those found in Quest 3. This means Quest 3S can play all the same apps and games as Quest 3—including the same Mixed Reality experiences. Plus, almost all Quest 3 accessories from Meta and third-party suppliers, such as head straps and facial interfaces, will also fit the Quest 3S.

With Quest 3S now available from just $299, this could be the perfect time to upgrade from Quest 2 if you haven’t already. It’s a great-value deal for newcomers to VR as well—or if you have another family member who wants to get into VR or play with you in local co-op. And, since the Quest 2 launched at the same price back in 2020 and went on to sell over 20 million units worldwide, we’re confident that the Quest 3S will perform well—and provide more users around the world with the most up-to-date standalone VR experiences and features.

[You can read more about our thoughts on the Quest 3S right here](https://medium.com/sidequestvr/quest-3s-could-be-the-most-important-vr-headset-of-2024-4b8da943692a).

# 2\. Quest 3 price cut—and discontinued 128GB model

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*bZ39lJpDLfSyDuJ-hx4aIg.png)

Coinciding with the Quest 3S launch, Meta also dropped the RRP of the Quest 3 512GB model to just **$499.** Meanwhile, they have ceased shipping the 128GB model altogether.

The Quest 3 ecosystem now comprises:

- 128GB Quest 3S ($299)
- 256GB Quest 3S ($399)
- 512GB Quest 3 ($499)

Not only is this a nice, even pricing structure, it also means that the Quest 3 and Quest 3S are perhaps the best value standalone VR headsets on the market right now—especially at the lowest and highest ends. These are both fantastic headsets, and Meta’s competitors are probably rethinking their own pricing strategies as a result.

There’s never been a better time to get into VR with such fantastic prices-to-value!

# 3\. Orion Augmented Reality glasses

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*yYK6TA17YJcUloZ5QJdNnA.png)

Perhaps the highlight of the keynote address was the unexpectedly in-depth prototype reveal of [Meta’s Orion AR glasses](https://about.meta.com/realitylabs/orion)—perhaps the most advanced pair of glasses the world has ever seen.

From the outside, they look like any ordinary pair of (thicc) glasses, weighing only 98g and paired with a sleek black wristband and wireless puck (without which, the glasses will not work). However, there’s a lot of technical wonder going on under the hood.

They were designed from the ground up to make communication and connection more accessible and fun, help you with daily tasks, play games, and be genuinely smart thanks to AI integration—all while being genuinely comfortable and stylish to wear.

# 4\. Meta AI

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*Yx3eGwWy7gaaFSP4-y0fbw.png)

AI is all the rage these days—and [Meta is no exception](https://ai.meta.com/). In fact, Connect 2024 focused on AI more than anything else, with the technology being mentioned in every segment of the keynote address and cropping up across many of the smaller talks and showcases over the 2 days. While it feels like a bit of a buzzword in tech—and has done for a few years now—Meta is actually doing some pretty cool (or creepy, depending on your outlook) stuff with AI—especially in the wearables field—that we need to talk about.

## Total AI integration

This isn’t ‘new’ news, but Meta is really pushing the power of AI across all of its platforms and products, especially in the form of its AI assistant, which is now powered by the [updated Llama 3.2](https://ai.meta.com/blog/llama-3-2-connect-2024-vision-edge-mobile-devices/)—Meta’s own LLM (Language Learning Model).

Their AI assistant is now fully integrated into WhatsApp, Facebook, Instagram, the latest generation of their Ray-Ban Meta smart glasses, and, of course, Quest headsets. You can ask it questions in real-time and, using your device and data, it will make recommendations depending on what you ask. Classic AI assistant stuff, then.

## Better vocal interaction

Slightly more impressive is the work Meta has been doing to improve vocal interactions with their AI assistant and make it feel more natural. They’ve even gone so far as to add celebrity voices to its AI chatbots, including Awkwafina, John Cena, and even Dame Judi Dench if you prefer a touch of British sophistication.

With Mark Zuckerberg himself believing that vocal interaction with AI is far more natural than text and presents the future of the tech’s development, these additions and updates are unsurprising.

## Image interpretation

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*P2-OQ3MdF46B9TVJek2fbg.png)

More impressive, still, is their work on AI image interpretation, with the software able to recognize (in many cases) what you’re looking at and answer questions based on what it sees—amongst other things.

These updates pair perfectly with the Ray-Ban Meta smart glasses and Quest headsets—and actually have a wide range of intriguing applications. You can look at an outfit laid out on your bed and ask how it would be accessorized. You can look at an animal and ask it for information about that animal. You can even look at your parking spot (if it’s numbered) and ask the AI to remember where you parked for you.

During the Orion glasses showcase, Meta also demonstrated the AI’s powers of recognition by letting it scan a group of ingredients and then provide recommendations on what to cook. The days of staring blankly at the fridge are over, it seems! Apparently, they’re also working on instant translation, so you won’t get stuck ordering off a foreign menu, either.

This power of image recognition also extends to image editing. Since the AI (broadly speaking) knows what it’s looking at, you can ask it to make changes and tweaks to images, too.

To allay any fears that this image recognition might be getting a bit too Black Mirror, Meta has stated that its recognition software will not work on humans. You won’t be able to track or recognize individuals. This is evidently due to (well-considered) safety and security concerns.

But, while this is impressive, none of this is exactly ‘new stuff’.

## Automatic video dubbing and live translation

What is new—and will surely come in very handy—is the ability for AI to detect the original language of a reel or short-form video and dub it into your native language—including an approximation of lip-synch. They’re currently only experimenting with English and Spanish, but the demo was impressive and showcased the AI’s ability to make an accurate dub, even when the content was spoken at speed.

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*qkPzvDW4Zv91vEQz9Vobvg.png)

You may soon be able to break language barriers with AI.

These translation developments will even extend to live conversations over time—as was also demonstrated during the keynote address. Zuckerberg was able to have a back-and-forth conversation in Spanish and English with a native speaker using the AI model integrated into the Ray-Bans they were both wearing. This is impressive stuff.

## AI impersonation…

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*gkak_ii0P2QAjd4wKiv-Aw.png)

Yeah… That’s an AI.

A final new feature (and definitely broke into Black Mirror territory—for me at least) was their new AI face generation, as demonstrated by Don Allen Stevenson III and Mark Zuckerberg.

Not only have they trained the AI model to impersonate Stevenson to help respond to DMs, emails, and more in his written style, they’ve fed it data on what he is—and isn’t—knowledgeable about so that it can provide more ‘Stevenson-accurate’ responses based on his real-life skills and experience. He knows a lot about writing and tech, but not so much about mountain climbing, as was demonstrated.

But the kicker was when Zuckerberg hopped onto a ‘video call’ with an AI representation of Stevenson and had it answer no only in his voice, but with his speaking style and subtle movements—and an approximation of his real-life knowledge, too.

This is cool. But it’s also really creepy.

# 5\. Ray-Ban Meta smart glasses updates

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*aunxQ1IOI6RmWp0ZhgTNog.png)

[Meta’s collab with Ray-Ban](https://meta.com/gb/smart-glasses/shop-all/?utm_source=gg&utm_medium=ps&utm_campaign=20687046214&utm_term=meta+ray+bans&utm_content=714820859989&utm_funnel=dcap&gad_source=1&gclid=CjwKCAjwgfm3BhBeEiwAFfxrG7pPs9bxcg7Txh6NMAoq_Nsml5PElXjeZUEidyRApRAsQLtkYM7rAhoC6mEQAvD_BwE&gclsrc=aw.ds) has produced some pretty awesome, functional, and fashionable wearables so far—with AI integration, video and photo cameras, and audio features that we’ve been loving, alongside the ability to answer calls and texts—and even get navigation assistance! And they’re getting better still!

A lot of these coming improvements will be in line with the AI advancements we’ve already discussed above, but let’s just summarize with: We can soon expect active recording, image, and object recognition, live translations, and more.

Meta’s AI integration with Ray-Bans has also expanded the app selection it’s compatible with — especially when it comes to audio. If you’re not a Spotify fan, you can also link up with Amazon Music, Audible, and more — with more promised over time.

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*Q314qNlGsRoORmh5_y6fSw.png)

Limited edition clear frames Ray-Ban Meta smart glasses.

Additionally, earlier product runs were difficult to get with transition lenses, but now there is a wider range available to suit your style, whether you want more traditional glasses or full-on shades. They’re also releasing a limited ‘clear frames’ edition of the glasses.

If you’ve not actually tried these smart glasses yet, we’d recommend that you do! Alongside the fact that they’re cool and stylish glasses you’d want to wear anyway, the functionality of these things is actually useful and may well represent the future of wearables.

# 6\. Developers to be given access to camera passthrough API

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*8vJ940ycVdyV1intF8BbZw.png)

We’re always excited by any reveal geared towards supporting developers—and this one could be key for the future of app development in passthrough!

Well, it appears Meta will finally be [granting developers access to their latest camera passthrough API](https://www.reddit.com/r/oculusdev/comments/1fq33l6/new_camera_passthrough_api_to_allow_some_amount/) (Application Programming Interface) from early next year, opening the doors to better apps and game development for Quest headsets.

While it’s unclear what form this will take, or how extensive this access will be, many developers will benefit from this as Meta has historically been very tight about camera access on Quest headsets due to privacy concerns.

It’s nice to see Meta make a move showing they care about developer feedback!

# 7\. New Horizon avatars

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*FZzIVrUUHkXNjpqkSg9DDA.png)

Out with the old and in with the new—Meta’s Horizon avatars are finally getting [the visual upgrade we’ve been waiting for since 2022](https://www.uploadvr.com/meta-avatars-legs-graphics-overhaul/)!

While introducing legs to their avatars was a popular move, there’s always been something a little too ‘uncanny valley’ about the Horizon avatars. They were stiff. Not human enough. Not customizable enough. And I don’t look anything like mine…

Well, now they’re getting… better!?

With this [latest update](https://medium.com/sidequestvr/new-meta-vr-avatars-to-be-announced-at-meta-connect-2024-8615b053c5f9), Meta has made improvements to the avatars’ visual style and included a suite of new options to help you fine-tune your look more than ever before. A particularly welcome change is greater control over body proportions—something that the older avatars were severely lacking. Many of the options now include sliders so you have more control over your appearance, so your avatar should look more distinctive than ever before.

Having played around with it myself (and you can try it too by visiting the Horizon app now!), I like the changes, however, I wish there had been more updates to the wardrobe and hair options. The wardrobe is mostly the same as before, while the hair options (and especially facial hair) just leave much to be desired.

Is it as good as the character creator in Dragon’s Dogma 2 or the latest Dragon Age? Absolutely not. But it’s better than the old one, and you should have fun playing with it!

# But, what about the games?

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:700/1*sP0Z3y0hKpxwvrfQg2rr9A.png)

Meta Connect 2024 was an AI-first event. While we got hands-on demos of the new Quest 3S and—perhaps even more exciting—the Orion AR glasses, the keynote, in particular, was really a showcase of Meta’s AI advancements, what it can do, and how it is helping them build the future of wearable tech.

In particular, we can’t wait to get hands-on with the live translation AI features—being a global company, this will definitely come in handy at SideQuest! We’re also very keen to follow the development of the Orion AR glasses—hopefully, we’ll have some consumer-ready products on the market sometime in the next 3 years!

In terms of games, there was a healthy buzz about upcoming apps and games launching before the end of 2024. With Quest 3S capable of running the same titles as Quest 3, anyone upgrading can look forward to more than [Batman: Arkham Shadow](https://www.meta.com/en-gb/experiences/batman-arkham-shadow/3551691271620960/)! We’ve also got [Metro Awakening](https://www.meta.com/en-gb/experiences/metro-awakening-deluxe-edition/5096918017089406/) (November) and [Alien: Rogue Incursion](https://www.meta.com/en-gb/experiences/alien-rogue-incursion/24882487241367228/) (December) poised to deliver some thrilling chills. And you can play the newly-released [Starship Home](https://sidequestvr.com/app/38071/starship-home) right now, which is a very cozy title built entirely for Mixed Reality! You won’t find any of these on Quest 2!

However, regardless of these amazing games coming up, one thing we found lacking throughout the event was any news on developer visibility on the Horizon Store.

Sure, there were several presentations and demos geared towards assisting developers—and granting developers access to their new camera passthrough API from early next year—but we didn't get any updates on the state of the transition away from App Lab and how indie developers may be able to get more traction on the Horizon Store.

Since App Lab was discontinued, developers were optimistic about Horizon Store restrictions relaxing, believing there would finally be a greater level of discovery for early access titles on the official storefront. However, this has not been the case and many developers we’re in conversation with are incredibly frustrated by this—and the lack of communication around it. Especially considering Meta seems to be promoting Horizon Worlds more than any other app right now—just look at the Horizon Store homepage!

We hope they address this soon.

Otherwise… What a show! We’ve got loads to look forward to over the next year (and beyond)—and plenty more adventures to have in eXtended Reality!

# Transcript: Mark Zuckerberg Announces Major Changes to Meta's Content Moderation Policies and Operations

Justin Hendrix / Jan 7, 2025

![ ](https://cdn.sanity.io/images/3tzzh18d/production/f6becbe102acd83451860b123e192a382dfb20de-1200x675.png)

Meta founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg. [Source](https://www.facebook.com/zuck/videos/1525382954801931/)

In a [video](https://www.facebook.com/watch/?v=1525382954801931&vanity=zuck) posted on Facebook and [text](https://www.threads.net/@zuck/post/DEhgZJYJu5D) posted to Threads, today Meta founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced sweeping changes to the company's approach to content moderation. After years of developing 'trust and safety' and content moderation systems and policies, Zuckerberg now asserts that "we've reached a point where it's just too many mistakes and too much censorship." Zuckerberg has decided to return to a posture that he believes will prioritize free expression.

Specific policy changes announced include:

- Eliminating fact-checkers in the US and replacing them with a "community notes" system similar to X (formerly Twitter);
- "Simplifying" content policies by removing certain restrictions on topics like immigration and gender;
- Changing enforcement approach for policy violations:
  - Focusing automated filters only on illegal and high-severity violations;
  - Requiring user reports before taking action on lower-severity violations;
  - Increasing the confidence threshold required before removing content;
  - Reintroducing civic and political content into recommendation systems on Facebook, Instagram, and Threads;
  - Relocating trust and safety and content moderation teams from California to Texas. "This will help remove the concern that biased employees are overly censoring content," Zuckerberg wrote on Threads.

Zuckerberg says he is planning to work with President-elect Donald Trump to oppose global "censorship" pressures. He makes claims about such pressures mounting in multiple regions, including:

- Europe's "ever-increasing number of laws, institutionalizing censorship";
- Secret courts in Latin America that "that can order companies to quietly take things down";
- Chinese censorship.

He further claims that the only way Meta "can push back on this global trend is with the support of the US government, and that's why it's been so difficult over the past four years when even the US government has pushed for censorship."

Zuckerberg's statement was timed with the [release of a post](https://about.fb.com/news/2025/01/meta-more-speech-fewer-mistakes/) by Meta Chief Global Affairs Officer Joel Kaplan:

> We want to undo the mission creep that has made our rules too restrictive and too prone to over-enforcement. We’re getting rid of a number of restrictions on topics like immigration, gender identity and gender that are the subject of frequent political discourse and debate. It’s not right that things can be said on TV or the floor of Congress, but not on our platforms.

Notably, Kaplan says the company is now deploying "AI large language models (LLMs) to provide a second opinion on some content before we take enforcement actions."

Timed with the announcement, Kaplan also provided an "exclusive" [interview](https://www.foxnews.com/politics/meta-ends-fact-checking-program-zuckerberg-vows-restore-free-expression-facebook-instagram) with the Fox News morning program "Fox & Friends."

_Below is a transcript of Zuckerberg's remarks, followed by a transcript of the Kaplan appearance on Fox & Friends:_

**Mark Zuckerberg:**

Hey everyone. I want to talk about something important today because it's time to get back to our roots around free expression on Facebook and Instagram. I started building social media to give people a voice. I gave a speech at Georgetown five years ago about the importance of protecting free expression, and I still believe this today, but a lot has happened over the last several years.

There's been widespread debate about the potential harms from online content. Governments and legacy media have pushed to censor more and more. A lot of this is clearly political, but there's also a lot of legitimately bad stuff out there. Drugs, terrorism, child exploitation. These are things that we take very seriously, and I want to make sure that we handle responsibly. So we built a lot of complex systems to moderate content, but the problem with complex systems is they make mistakes even if they accidentally censor just 1% of posts.

That's millions of people, and we've reached a point where it's just too many mistakes and too much censorship. The recent elections also feel like a cultural tipping point towards, once again, prioritizing speech. So, we're going to get back to our roots and focus on reducing mistakes, simplifying our policies, and restoring free expression on our platforms. More specifically, here's what we're going to do.

First, we're going to get rid of fact-checkers and replace them with community notes similar to X starting in the US. After Trump first got elected in 2016, the legacy media wrote nonstop about how misinformation was a threat to democracy. We tried in good faith to address those concerns without becoming the arbiters of truth, but the fact-checkers have just been too politically biased and have destroyed more trust than they've created, especially in the US. So, over the next couple of months, we're going to phase in a more comprehensive community notes system.

Second, we're going to simplify our content policies and get rid of a bunch of restrictions on topics like immigration and gender that are just out of touch with mainstream discourse. What started as a movement to be more inclusive has increasingly been used to shut down opinions and shut out people with different ideas, and it's gone too far. So, I want to make sure that people can share their beliefs and experiences on our platforms.

Third, we're changing how we enforce our policies to reduce the mistakes that account for the vast majority of censorship on our platforms. We used to have filters that scanned for any policy violation. Now, we're going to focus those filters on tackling illegal and high-severity violations, and for lower-severity violations, we're going to rely on someone reporting an issue before we take action. The problem is that the filters make mistakes, and they take down a lot of content that they shouldn't. So, by dialing them back, we're going to dramatically reduce the amount of censorship on our platforms. We're also going to tune our content filters to require much higher confidence before taking down content. The reality is that this is a trade-off. It means we're going to catch less bad stuff, but we'll also reduce the number of innocent people's posts and accounts that we accidentally take down.

Fourth, we're bringing back civic content. For a while, the community asked to see less politics because it was making people stressed, so we stopped recommending these posts, but it feels like we're in a new era now, and we're starting to get feedback that people want to see this content again. So we're going to start phasing this back into Facebook, Instagram, and Threads while working to keep the communities friendly and positive. Fifth, we're going to move our trust and safety and content moderation teams out of California, and our US-based content review is going to be based in Texas. As we work to promote free expression, I think that will help us build trust to do this work in places where there is less concern about the bias of our teams.

Finally, we're going to work with President Trump to push back on governments around the world. They're going after American companies and pushing to censor more. The US has the strongest constitutional protections for free expression in the world. Europe has an ever-increasing number of laws, institutionalizing censorship, and making it difficult to build anything innovative there. Latin American countries have secret courts that can order companies to quietly take things down. China has censored our apps from even working in the country. The only way that we can push back on this global trend is with the support of the US government, and that's why it's been so difficult over the past four years when even the US government has pushed for censorship.

By going after us and other American companies, it has emboldened other governments to go even further. But now we have the opportunity to restore free expression, and I'm excited to take it. It'll take time to get this right, and these are complex systems. They're never going to be perfect. There's also a lot of illegal stuff that we still need to work very hard to remove. But the bottom line is that after years of having our content moderation work focused primarily on removing content, it is time to focus on reducing mistakes, simplifying our systems, and getting back to our roots about giving people voice. I'm looking forward to this next chapter. Stay good out there, and more to come soon.

Meta Platforms, formerly Facebook, has transformed from a college project into one of the world’s most powerful tech companies. As of December 2024, Meta's market capitalization stands at approximately $1.48 trillion, making it the [world's 7th most valuable company](https://companiesmarketcap.com/meta-platforms/marketcap/?utm_source=chatgpt.com). With a market capitalization surpassing $1 trillion as of 2024 and over [3 billion monthly active users](https://www.statista.com/statistics/272014/global-social-networks-ranked-by-number-of-users/?utm_source=chatgpt.com) across its platforms, Meta’s influence is undeniably strong. But this success isn’t just driven by its widespread social media reach or its ambitious Metaverse vision. Here's an inside look at Meta’s financial growth journey and how the company is revolutionizing the digital economy.

### The Early Expansions

Meta's journey toward global tech dominance began with its public debut in 2012, raising $16 billion in an IPO that valued the company at $104 billion. By the end of that year, [Facebook](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/technology/facebook-reaches-1-billion-users/2012/10/04/5edfefb2-0e14-11e2-bb5e-492c0d30bff6_story.html) (before merging into Meta) had surpassed 1 billion users. In the following years, Facebook's growth was driven by strategic acquisitions, such as [Instagram](https://archive.nytimes.com/dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/04/09/facebook-buys-instagram-for-1-billion/) for $1 billion in 2012, strengthening its presence in photo-sharing, and [WhatsApp](https://www.forbes.com/sites/parmyolson/2014/10/06/facebook-closes-19-billion-whatsapp-deal/) for $19 billion in 2014, expanding its mobile messaging capabilities. These acquisitions set the stage for the rebranding of Facebook's virtual reality division as "Facebook Reality Labs" in 2016, reflecting a growing commitment to AR and VR technologies. As Zuckerberg began to focus on the long-term potential of the Metaverse, Meta committed to pouring over $10 billion into [Meta’s Reality Labs](https://www.theverge.com/2021/10/25/22745381/facebook-reality-labs-10-billion-metaverse) division, positioning it at the forefront of the next wave of internet innovation.

### The Stock and Investor Surge

Due to Meta’s impressive long-term growth potential as a leading AI tech company, investors have been flocking to the strategically restructured company. [Analysts](https://www.forbes.com/sites/greatspeculations/2024/12/10/whats-behind-the-80-rise-in-meta-stock/) noted that Meta’s combination of AI-powered advertising tools and its growth in immersive technologies make it a compelling investment, thus resulting in a [80% stock increase](https://investor.atmeta.com/home/default.aspx) in 2024. Additionally, Meta’s commitment to enhancing its [AR/VR hardware](https://technologymagazine.com/articles/how-meta-is-dominating-the-ar-vr-market-amid-global-demand) and software has placed it at the forefront of the immersive technology industry. Looking ahead, Meta’s stock is expected to average around [$697.66](https://coincodex.com/stock/META/price-prediction/?utm_source=chatgpt.com) in 2025, which is a 19% increase compared to the company’s stock price in 2024. Meta's strong financial performance and positive analyst forecasts have significantly enhanced investor confidence, positioning the company for continued success in the evolving digital landscape.

### The Advertising Juggernaut

Despite Meta’s growing focus on the Metaverse, its advertising business remains the core of its revenue model. By utilizing their digital advertising platforms, such as Facebook, Instagram, and Whatsapp, Meta is able to provide advertisers hyper-targeted ads across diverse demographics, which is key to its success. Despite challenges from big competitors like [Google and Tiktok,](https://www.forbes.com/sites/greatspeculations/2024/12/10/whats-behind-the-80-rise-in-meta-stock/) Meta’s advertising revenue exceeded [$130 billion](https://investor.atmeta.com/financials/) in 2024, solidifying its position as a leading player in the global digital advertising market. This advertising strength continues to be the primary driver of Meta's financial growth, even as it pushes into new frontiers like the Metaverse and immersive digital experiences. As long as Meta can continue to innovate and provide value to advertisers, its advertising business will remain a critical pillar of its overall strategy.

Meta's journey offers valuable lessons for businesses in any industry, especially when it comes to staying ahead of digital trends and diversifying revenue streams. By strategically diversifying its revenue streams and heavily investing in emerging technologies, Meta has positioned itself at the forefront of the digital economy. The company's robust 2024 performance, with a [19% year-over-year revenue increase](https://www.forbes.com/sites/gurufocus/2024/11/14/ai-powers-metas-strong-q3-growth-profits-soar/), highlights its resilience despite significant investments in new sectors. Additionally, their confidence in the Metaverse fostered a strong investment source, serving as reminder for B2B companies to prioritize long-term growth initiatives. By embracing these strategies, growth-seeking companies can not only survive but thrive in an increasingly digital and competitive landscape.

## Orion: Prototype AR Glasses

![APTOPIX Meta Connect Conference](https://imageio.forbes.com/specials-images/imageserve/66f5c9bf113d5c525667b49b/APTOPIX-Meta-Connect-Conference/960x0.jpg?format=jpg&width=1440)

Perhaps the most exciting announcement was for a product with a release date that remains a mystery. In a noteworthy reveal, Zuckerberg presented a prototype of Meta's first augmented reality glasses, codenamed Orion. These AR glasses represent significant research and development efforts, with echoes of Google’s scrapped Glass project from 2015.

Orion works by overlaying virtual information over a user’s view by using light diffraction to create holographic projections in their field of view. Zuckerberg stated that the display is different from anything else consumers have used, in the sense that it’s not actually a screen. Instead, it’s a different type of display technology that uses small projectors in the arms of the glasses, which emit light into nanoscale 3D structures etched into the lenses.

While Meta has not announced a release date for Orion, the prototype demonstrates the company's ongoing investment in AR technology, with unique technology that has the potential to make it stand out from similar offerings from the likes of the Immersed Visor, and even Apple’s much bulkier Vision Pro headset. These glasses could potentially change how users interact with digital information in everyday scenarios, from navigation to real-time translation and entertainment, and with a large play like Meta joining the fray, there could be an increased chance for higher rates of adoption for such technology further down the line.

## Quest 3S: A More Affordable Mixed Reality Option

A Meta employee sets up a Quest 3S, a new entry-level model of Meta's mixed reality headset, for ... \[+\] demonstrations for content creators and journalists ahead of Meta Connect, Meta's annual event on its latest software and hardware innovations, in Menlo Park, California, on September 24, 2024. Another key announcement was the Meta Quest 3S, a more affordable version of last year's Quest 3 headset. Priced at $299, the Quest 3S aims to make mixed reality experiences accessible to a broader audience, and its RRP is a stark contrast to the $3,499 asking price of Apple's Vision Pro.

While it may not include all the features of its higher-priced Quest 3 or Apple counterpart, the Quest 3S retains the core mixed reality capabilities of the Quest 3, allowing users to integrate virtual elements with their physical surroundings. The headset also features spatial audio by Dolby Atmos and can function as a remote desktop for Windows 11 PCs, leveraging Meta's partnership with Microsoft.

## AI Developments

Meta also used Connect as an opportunity to share its AI advancements, introducing various new features across its platforms. A significant announcement was Llama 3.2, Meta's latest AI model capable of processing both images and text — a first for the company's open-source offerings.

This multimodal approach expands possibilities for developers, potentially enabling more advanced AI applications. Examples include augmented reality apps with real-time video understanding, visual search engines and document analysis tools. In addition, Meta introduced voice capabilities for its AI assistant, including celebrity voice options such as John Cena, Dame Judi Dench and Kristen Bell.

Other AI-powered features include real-time language translation through Meta's Ray-Ban smart glasses and automatic video dubbing for content on Instagram and Facebook. These tools could be particularly useful for content creators and marketers aiming to reach global audiences — although the [EU AI Act](https://www.forbes.com/councils/forbestechcouncil/2024/09/19/how-the-eu-ai-act-stands-to-impact-business/#:~:text=The%20European%20Union%20member%20states,t%20be%20the%20first%20time. ## Ray-Ban Meta Smart Glasses: New Features

![Meta Connect Conference](https://imageio.forbes.com/specials-images/imageserve/66f5c9e1a871f72d321714d0/Meta-Connect-Conference/960x0.jpg?format=jpg&width=1440)

Meta announced updates to its smart glasses line-up, developed in collaboration with Ray-Ban. The latest version includes improved AI integration, designed to facilitate more natural interactions with Meta's virtual assistant and enhance object recognition capabilities.

New features include video AI, real-time translation and expanded content partnerships with services like Spotify, Amazon Music and Audible. These additions clearly aim to strengthen the position of Ray-Ban Meta smart glasses in the wearable tech market.

## Looking Ahead

Overall, Meta's continued investment in mixed reality and AI technologies indicates the company's view of these areas as foundational to future computing platforms. By introducing more affordable hardware like the Quest 3S and developing prototypes like Orion, Meta is working toward a future where digital and physical realities are increasingly integrated.

Challenges remain, including user adoption rates, privacy concerns and regulatory considerations. However, Meta's announcements at Connect 2024 demonstrate its commitment to shaping human-computer interaction, which is an area that founder Mark Zuckerberg is clearly betting big on.
